{{Infobox venue | name = Štark Arena | native_name = Штарк Арена | native_name_lang = sr | logo_image = File:starkarena.png | logo_caption = Official logo | image = Belgrade Arena, south entrance 1, Feb 2011.jpg | caption = | image_size = 250px | address = Bulevar Arsenija Čarnojevića 58 | location = [[New Belgrade]], [[Belgrade]], Serbia | coordinates = {{coord|44|48|50.95|N|20|25|16.89|E|type:landmark|display=inline, title}} | broke_ground = 1991 | opened = {{start date and age|2004|07|31|df=yes}} | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[City of Belgrade]] | operator = "Arena Beograd" [[Types of business entity#Serbia|d.o.o.]]
[[Goran Grbović]] (CEO) | construction_cost = [[Euro|€]]70 Million | architect = Vlada Slavica | main_contractors = {{plain list| *[[Energoprojekt]] *GP Napred }} | former_names = Belgrade Arena (2004–2012)
Kombank Arena (2012–2017) | tenants = [[Serbia men's national basketball team]] {{small|(2006–present)}} | former_tenants = | capacity = 18,386https://starkarena.co.rs/o-%D1%88/?lang=en | website = {{URL|http://starkarena.co.rs/en}} }} {{OSM Location map | coord = {{coord|44|48|50.95|N|20|25|16.89|E|type:landmark}} | zoom = 12 | width = 300 | height = 200 | caption = Location within New Belgrade | mark-coord = {{coord|44|48|50.95|N|20|25|16.89|E|type:landmark}} | label = | label-pos = top | mark-title = | mark-image = | mark-description = }} The '''Štark Arena''' (originally known as '''Belgrade Arena''') is a multi-purpose [[indoor arena]] located in [[Belgrade]], Serbia. It is designed as a universal hall for sports, cultural events and other programs. The venue is used for several different sports events, such as [[basketball]], [[concerts]], [[futsal]], [[handball]], [[judo]], [[table tennis]], [[tennis]], [[volleyball]] and [[water polo]]. Its total floor area stands at 48,000 square meters.{{cite web|url=http://www.beograd.rs/cms/view.php?id=44326|title=Страница није пронађена.|website=Град Београд - Званична интернет презентација - Страница није пронађена.}} For sports, it has a seating [[Seating capacity|capacity]] of up to 18,386 seats, of which 860 seats are grouped in 70 luxury boxes.https://starkarena.co.rs/o-%D1%88/?lang=en Štark Arena is a member of the [[European Arenas Association]] (EAA).{{cite web|url=http://www.europeanarenas.com/index.php|title=Official Website of European Arenas Association|publisher=[[European Arenas Association|EAA]]|accessdate=2016-06-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307094728/http://www.europeanarenas.com/index.php|archive-date=2016-03-07|dead-url=yes|df=}} ==Location and influence== The Belgrade Arena is situated in New Belgrade. Arena's parking is limited in spaces, though nearby residential areas provide enough room for vehicles. It's a 10 min walk from [[Novi Beograd railway station]], which offers international train services from [[Austria]], [[Hungary]], [[Slovenia]] and [[Croatia]], domestic train services (fast and regional trains) to and from [[Novi Sad railway station|Novi Sad]], [[Subotica railway station|Subotica]] and [[Šid railway station|Šid]] and urban rail services [[BG Voz]]. It takes a 15-minute drive from [[Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport]] to the arena. Ride from downtown Belgrade would take the same amount of time, unless in rush-hour, when it could take up to 30 minutes to get to central [[Novi Beograd]], where the arena is located. The construction of the arena has caused a substantial increase in prices for apartments in the surrounding area, which are mostly new. A new modern business district is scheduled to be constructed across the Belgrade Arena. Hotel IN was the first new hotel to be built near the arena however the venue is also within walking distance from [[Hyatt Regency Belgrade]] and [[Crowne Plaza Belgrade]]. ==Name== During its construction, the provisory name of the arena was "Hala Limes". Yet, when the construction of the arena was finished in 2004, it was given the official name ''Beogradska Arena'' (Belgrade Arena). In February 2007, Serbian basketball coach [[Božidar Maljković]] started an initiative to name the Arena after another renowned Serbian basketball coach, [[Aleksandar Nikolić]]. Maljković presented his initiative to the city officials and the president of Serbia [[Boris Tadić]], but the name change hasn't been accepted.{{cite web|url=http://www.blic.rs/stara_arhiva/sport/145364/Profesor-Aleksandar-Nikolic-je-zasluzio-da-Arena-nosi-ime-po|title=Profesor Aleksandar Nikolić je zaslužio da 'Arena' nosi ime po|date=17 December 2015|publisher=}} Instead, in 2016, another Belgrade sports hall, ''Pionir Hall'' was renamed ''[[Hall Aleksandar Nikolić]]''. [[File:kombank-arena.png|237px|thumb|Logo used for the arena from 2012 to 2017.]] In June 2012, the arena officials signed a five-year agreement with [[Komercijalna banka]] to change the name to "Kombank Arena", and the name change became official in September 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportspromedia.com/news/new_name_for_serbias_belgrade_arena/|title=New name for Serbia’s Belgrade Arena|publisher=}} During [[UEFA Futsal Euro 2016]], which has been held in February 2016, the Arena has been renamed from Kombank Arena to Belgrade Arena, for sponsorship reasons.{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/futsaleuro/season=2016/finals/venueguide/index.html |title=Belgrade Arena |publisher= [[UEFA]] |date=2015-09-25 |accessdate=2016-01-31}}{{cite web|url=http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/sport.294.html:584981-%D0%A3%D0%95%D0%A4%D0%90-%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%80%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%B0-%D0%90%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%83 |title=UEFA prekrstila "Arenu"! |publisher= [[Večernje novosti]] |date=2016-01-08 |accessdate=2016-01-31}} In October 2017, the arena was once again renamed, this time to Štark Arena, following the signing of a five-year sponsorship deal with [[Štark]], a food manufacturing company.{{cite web|url=http://www.rts.rs/page/stories/ci/story/124/drustvo/2902059/beogradska-arena-ce-pet-godina-nositi-naziv-stark-arena.html|title=Београдска арена ће пет година носити назив "Штарк арена"|publisher=RTS|date=12 October 2017|accessdate=19 November 2017}} ==History== ===Design and construction=== In 1989, The City of Belgrade was chosen to host the [[1994 FIBA World Championship|Basketball World Championship of 1994]].[http://www.24sec.net/article.asp?index=175 24sec.net - Basketball News - Diamond Ball preview!] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071019175934/http://www.24sec.net/article.asp?index=175 |date=2007-10-19 }} However, there was a condition for the city to build an all-new basketball arena. In the competition for the design of a new arena with seat capacity of at least 20,000, the winner was the design submitted by Belgrade architect Vlada Slavica from [[Energoprojekt]]. In 1991 a location for the project was chosen – [[Blokovi|Blok 25]] in [[New Belgrade]]. The project was carried out amid significant difficulties. For starters, the construction of such a mega structure had to meet a very tight deadline, since it was only 3 years to the World Championships. A team of 126 companies was formed to be part of the arena committee, with [[Energoprojekt Visokogradnja]] and GP Napred as main contractors{{cite web|url=http://www.planeta.org.rs/10/arhitektura.htm|title=BEOGRADSKA ARENA: arhitekta VLADA SLAVICA}}{{cite web|url=https://www.vreme.com/cms/view.php?id=309801|title=Dom za češanje}}. Two architects were chosen to design the arena's roof. In 1992 construction started as the arena committee formed a partnership with American company [[Populous (company)|HOK]], experienced in building sporting venues. However, tough times were ahead. As the [[Yugoslav wars|disintegration of Yugoslavia]] started, the [[United Nations]] imposed sanctions on the [[Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]] and HOK stopped all co-operation with the arena committee. Even with this setback, work on the Belgrade Arena continued. In 1993, Belgrade suffered one of its worst economic years in modern history. The Federal Republic of Yugoslavia experienced record inflation rates, and as a result of the sanctions and the conflicts in Yugoslavia, Belgrade lost the right to host the 1994 Basketball World Championships.[http://www.novosti.rs/code/navigate.php?Id=13&status=jedna&vest=100673&datum=2007-03-05 Novosti | Vecernje novosti | Sport] Following the formal announcement by [[FIBA]], the arena's construction still continued for some time, though at a considerably slower pace due to the lack of material. However, sometime in 1995 the construction completely stopped. Work on the arena re-commenced in 1998 as the city was chosen to host the [[1999 World Table Tennis Championships]] to be held in the Belgrade Arena. By this time the roof was already taking shape towards completion, part of the façade was done and the interior was half complete. Once again, Yugoslavia lost the privilege to host the competition as the city was [[1999 NATO bombing of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|bombed by NATO forces]] the year the competition was supposed to be held. The first public event held in the Arena (which was still under construction at the time) was the final [[Slobodan Milošević]] (president of Yugoslavia at the time) [[Federal Republic of Yugoslavia presidential election, 2000|2000 presidential election campaign rally]], which was held September 20, 2000.{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/info/vesti/index.php?yyyy=2000&mm=09&dd=20&nav_category=1&nav_id=12114 |title=Centralna promocija liste kandidata SPS i JUL |publisher=[[B92]] |date=2000-09-20 |accessdate=2010-02-17|language=Serbian}} This was the last time Milošević has held a public speech. ===Completion=== After a change of government in Yugoslavia in 2000 and the lifting of all sanctions imposed on the country, the Arena, under new management, was completed in 2004 in time for the [[FIBA Diamond Ball|FIBA Diamond Ball tournament]] and Belgrade finally got the right to host [[EuroBasket 2005|The 2005 European Basketball Championship]].{{cite web|url=http://www.arhiva.srbija.gov.rs/news/2002-03/09/323020.html|title=Belgrade to host EuroBasket 2005|publisher=}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Temporary licenses for public use expired in early 2006, following a series of sport events and concerts in 2005. Works on an automated fire prevention system and installation of elevators to meet European standards were completed by November 2006, while no events were held in the Arena in the meantime. The Belgrade Arena received its permanent public use license on November 4, 2006 and re-opened its doors as a result.{{cite web|url=http://www.novosti.rs/code/navigate.php?Id=13&status=jedna&vest=100673&datum=2007-03-04|title=Najskuplja kad je - prazna|website=www.novosti.rs}} ==Events== [[File:Srb,Brz,Arena.jpg|thumb|320px|[[Serbia men's national volleyball team|Serbia]] - [[Brazil men's national volleyball team|Brazil]] [[FIVB World League 2009]] final, 22,680 spectators]] The ''[[List of events held in Štark Arena]]'' lists both past and upcoming events. The first event held in the Belgrade Arena was a [[Socialist Party of Serbia]] and [[Yugoslav Left]] final election campaign rally, held September 20, 2000 before the [[Federal Republic of Yugoslavia presidential election, 2000|2000 elections in Yugoslavia]]. The construction of the Arena wasn't finished at that time. The official opening came nearly four years later, July 31, 2004, when the ''[[FIBA Diamond Ball]]'' basketball tournament was held. Since Arena had only temporary license, only several events were held during the next two and a half years. The first event held after getting permanent license was the [[50 Cent]] concert, on November 6, 2006. One of the biggest events to take place in the Arena was the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2008]]. In the final night of the contest an audience of over 20,000 was present. Other big events held in the Arena include numerous sporting events, notably the European championships in [[basketball]] ([[EuroBasket 2005]]), [[volleyball]] ([[2005 Men's European Volleyball Championship]]), [[table tennis]] ([[Table Tennis European Championships|2007 European Table Tennis Championships]]), and [[judo]] ([[2007 European Judo Championships]]). The Belgrade Arena was also one of the 69 venues to take part in the [[2009 Summer Universiade|2009 Summer Universiade Games]], hosting the opening and closing ceremonies, as well as the [[Basketball at the 2009 Summer Universiade|basketball competition]]. Arena was the host venue for the concerts of the most significant artists of Serbia and former Yugoslavia, as well as major international stars, including [[50 Cent]], [[Anastacia]], [[Backstreet Boys]], [[Beyoncé]], [[Andrea Bocelli]], [[Montserrat Caballe]], [[Nick Cave]], [[The Chemical Brothers]], [[Eric Clapton]] and [[Steve Winwood]], [[Joe Cocker]], [[Leonard Cohen]], [[Phil Collins]], [[The Cult]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Fatboy Slim]], [[Peter Gabriel]], [[Guano Apes]], [[Guns N' Roses]], [[Hurts]], [[Il Divo]], [[Iron Maiden]], [[Jean Michel Jarre]], [[Elton John]], [[Tom Jones (singer)|Tom Jones]], [[Judas Priest]], [[Alicia Keys]], [[Mark Knopfler]], [[Lenny Kravitz]], [[Massive Attack]], [[Nicole Scherzinger]] and [[The Pussycat Dolls]], [[Queen + Paul Rodgers]], [[Eros Ramazzotti]], [[Jennifer Lopez]], [[Rammstein]], [[Chris Rea]], [[RBD]], [[Rihanna]], [[Sade (band)|Sade]], [[Simple Minds]], [[Shakira]], [[Slash (musician)|Slash]], [[Slayer]], [[Slipknot (band)|Slipknot]], [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], [[Whitesnake]], [[Roger Waters]], [[Zaz (singer)|Zaz]], [[ZZ Top]], [[OneRepublic]] and many others. The Arena also hosted the second [[Green Fest (Serbia)|Green Fest music festival]] with performances by [[Franz Ferdinand (band)|Franz Ferdinand]], [[Cypress Hill]] and [[The Raveonettes]], the [[Jelen Pivo Live|IQ festival]] headlined by [[Marilyn Manson (band)|Marylin Manson]], and many other concerts, political rallies, product exhibitions and numerous other events. Also, in several international competitions, the record attendance has been set at the Arena. On February 2, 2009, the [[2009 Fed Cup]] [[2009 Fed Cup World Group II|World Group II]], [[Serbia Fed Cup team|Serbia]] vs. [[Japan Fed Cup team|Japan]] [[tennis]] match set a record for an [[International Tennis Federation|ITF]] event attendance with a crowd of 15,118 spectators.{{cite web|url=http://www.politika.rs/rubrike/Sport/Tenis/Ovacije-teniskim-junakinjama-u-Areni.lt.html |title=Ovacije teniskim junakinjama u "Areni" |publisher=Politika |date=2009-02-09 |accessdate=2009-03-06}} On March 5, 2009, the first [[KK Partizan|Partizan Belgrade]] [[basketball]] game at Belgrade Arena was held, a [[Euroleague 2008–09|2008–09]] [[Euroleague]] [[Euroleague 2008–09#Top 16|Top 16]] match against [[A1 Ethniki|Greek]] powerhouse [[Panathinaikos BC|Panathinaikos]]. A crowd of 22,567, a record for the Euroleague, saw Partizan win 63–56.{{cite web|url=http://www.euroleague.net/item/45551 |title=Partizan sets crowd record at Belgrade Arena! |publisher=Euroleague.net |date=2009-03-05 |accessdate=2009-03-06}} On July 26, 2009, the [[FIVB World League]] final between [[Serbia men's national volleyball team|Serbia]] and [[Brazil men's national volleyball team|Brazil]] was held in Belgrade Arena, with an attendance of 22,680, which is a record of World League.{{cite web|url=http://www.fivb.org/en/Infomedia/PressReleaseDB.asp?No=21752&Language=0|title=Infomedia|website=www.fivb.org}} On March 26, 2014, [[KK Crvena zvezda|Crvena Zvezda]] played [[2013–14 Eurocup Basketball|Eurocup]] quarterfinal game against Ukrainian champions [[BC Budivelnyk|Budivelnyk Kiev]]. Zvezda won in the overtime 79–70 and this match gathered 24,232 spectators, which is a record for the Eurocup and also for any basketball game held indoors in Europe. This is also a record attendance of Belgrade Arena.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurocupbasketball.com/eurocup/news/i/134631|title=Crvena Zvezda Telekom's sets new European attendance record|publisher=}} The attendance of 18,473 at the final match of the [[2016 Men's European Water Polo Championship]], between [[Serbia men's national water polo team|Serbia]] and [[Montenegro men's national water polo team|Montenegro]] was the highest one in water polo history.{{cite web |url=http://www.len.eu/Press/D14%20Summary%20-%20European%20Water%20Polo%20Championships,%20Belgrade.aspx |title=Serbia completes hattrick in front of 18,000 fans |publisher=[[LEN]] |date=2016-01-23 |accessdate=2016-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160127225720/http://len.eu/Press/D14%20Summary%20-%20European%20Water%20Polo%20Championships,%20Belgrade.aspx |archivedate=2016-01-27 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/sport/vaterpolo/vesti.php?yyyy=2016&mm=01&dd=25&nav_id=1089131 |title=Rekord u Areni, finale gledalo 18.473 ljudi |publisher=[[B92]] |date=2016-01-25 |accessdate=2016-01-25}} The [[2018 EuroLeague Final Four]] was held at Štark Arena in May 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.euroleaguebasketball.net/euroleague-basketball/news/i/7d467dgwbghta4lo|title=The Final Four goes to Belgrade in 2018!|publisher=Euroleague Basketball|date=26 October 2016|accessdate=4 December 2016}} ==Gallery== Belgrade Arena west.jpg|Belgrade Arena in 2006 (west entrance) Belgrade Arena north.jpg|Belgrade Arena in 2007 (north entrance) File:Belgrade Arena, south entrance 1, Feb 2011.jpg|Belgrade Arena in 2011 (south entrance) Arena Beograd.jpg|Belgrade Arena during [[2012 European Men's Handball Championship]] 2016 European Water Polo Championship -
